thread.title: Maryville rolls past William Blount, 42-0
thread.title_full: Maryville rolls past William Blount, 42-0 - PrepXtra Story

author: knoxnews.com
title: Maryville rolls past William Blount, 42-0
text:
MARYVILLE â€” Since all Class 6A teams now make the football playoffs, Maryville High School's team didn't necessarily need a tune-up with the postseason looming.
But a 42-0 victory over neighbor William Blount provided the Rebels' defense a chance to show off and give some younger players quality playing time.
Coming off a bye week, the Rebels limited the Governors to 89 total yards, put up 388 yards on offense and received a solid outing from sophomore quarterback Dylan Hopkins.
Hopkins, who took over under center full time early in October after Austin Ensley was suspended from the team, completed 9 of 13 passes for 151 yards and a passing touchdown and also ran for a score.
The victory marked the 38th consecutive win for Maryville (8-0, 5-0 Region 1-6A), dating back to the beginning of the 2013 season.
"The defense got another shutout and we never want to take those for granted," Maryville coach George Quarles said.
William Blount (2-6, 0-5) couldn't get anything going offensively, passing for just 48 yards and rushing for 41 thanks to several Maryville sacks and tackles for loss.
Joel Hopkins put the Rebels on the board on their initial drive with a 7-yard touchdown run and sophomore standout Isaiah Cobb upped the lead to 14-0 on Maryville's next drive with a 7-yard run.
Shelby Brock showed off his speed with a 61-yard touchdown reception on the Rebels' third possession. After a William Blount fumble in Rebels' territory, Maryville turned a short field into a 28-0 halftime advantage shortly before the half when Jordan Ervin reeled in a 14-yard touchdown reception from Hopkins.
Hopkins made it 35-0 on the Rebels' first drive of the second half with an 18-yard keeper up the middle and junior Jae Williams added the final score with a 6-yard run up the middle with just over two minutes to go.
"Dylan has played well," Quarles said. "He is still kind of unsure of how to lead and be that out-front guy and we are okay with that.
"It is a lot to put on a sophomore to have to be the guy, but I think he has handled everything really well."
Matthew Reagan is a freelance contributor.
